title: How to Prepare for a Camping Trip

steps.title: Determine with whom you are camping.
steps.content: Determine with whom you are camping. If it is just you or your family, the next step is not quite as important. However, if you are taking a scout troop or a group of friends or are required to camp with your classmates as part of a comprehensive outdoor education program, read the next steps carefully.

steps.title: Make sure you get insurance information and health information before you do anything else.
steps.content: Make sure you get insurance information and health information before you do anything else. If someone is injured on the trip, the insurance information will make a huge difference in the care they receive. [1] X Research source Health information is very important in planning the trip, for example, you cannot pack peanut butter if your friend is allergic to peanuts. If someone who is coming needs routine medication, make sure they have it. If they wear glasses or contacts, make sure they have a case, saline (contacts only), and/or a spare pair of glasses. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Set up a first aid kit.
steps.content: Set up a first aid kit. If you are not sure what to put in it, read "Things You'll Need". You should also teach yourself, general First Aid.

steps.title: Decide how long you will stay and figure out where and with whom you will be sleeping.
steps.content: Decide how long you will stay and figure out where and with whom you will be sleeping. If you do not know this, you will go through the trouble of purchasing and packing a tent when one may already be provided for you.

steps.title: Pack an appropriate amount of food:
steps.content: Pack an appropriate amount of food: Enough for three meals and an optional snack per day. Try not to pack too many perishable food items, like cheese, chicken, and milk. Basically, try to avoid dairy products and meat, because they can make you sick if you eat them when they go bad. [3] X Trustworthy Source US National Park Service Agency responsible for the maintenance and promotion of national parks and monuments Go to source Trail mix is great for snacks, fruit for breakfast, crackers for lunch, and leftovers for dinner. Also, remember to pack lots of water. Try sticking with dehydrated foods that can easily be prepared with boiling water. This way, you can make a “home-cooked” meal over the campfire.

steps.title: Gather all of the other things on the "Things You'll Need" list and try to pack them in a small, lightweight bag.
steps.content: Gather all of the other things on the "Things You'll Need" list and try to pack them in a small, lightweight bag. You can put smaller items in a backpack or rolling suitcase and the larger items like your sleeping bag can be carried in a garbage bag. They are great for carrying and can be folded and stubbed into a small space until needed.

steps.title: Load everything into your car or bus and hit the road!
steps.content: Load everything into your car or bus and hit the road!
